Award.AwardTitle: Middle-to-Late Jurassic terrestrial vertebrates of China: Systematics and geochronology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Middle-to-Late Jurassic terrestrial vertebrates of China: Systematics
and geochronology

PI: James M Clark, George Washington University
Co-PIs: Catherine A. Forster, GWU; Xu Xing, Chinese Academy of Sciences

Land-living vertebrate fossils from the Middle and early Late Jurassic (176-156 million years ago) are very poorly known worldwide, but the Shishugou Formation of NW China preserves abundant articulated skeletons from this age. This is an important time in the history of modern land vertebrates, because the oldest occurrences of modern mammals, lizards, turtles, and salamanders are this age or slightly older, and the presence of the oldest bird Archaeopteryx later in the Jurassic indicates that birds evolved at about this time. The major lineages of dinosaurs that flourished in the Cretaceous (ceratopsians, ankylosaurs, ornithopods, neosauropods, and coelurosaurs) also appear at this time.
From 2001-2006 joint expeditions by GWU and the Chinese Academy of Sciences to the Shishugou Formation, funded in 2004-2006 by the NSF, collected over 450 vertebrate fossils and documented the geology of the formation. We radiometrically dated rocks indicating the formation spans the Middle-Upper Jurassic boundary. Among our discoveries are the oldest and most primitive tyrannosauroid (Guanlong wucaii) and ceratopsian (Yinlong downsi) dinosaurs, the first ceratosaurian theropod dinosaur from Asia (Limusaurus inextricabilis), and the oldest and most primitive member of the bizarre alvarezsaurid theropods. Fossils in this collection bear important evidence on the origin of birds, generating a new hypothesis for the identity of the fingers present in theropods and documenting the diversification of the closest relatives of birds 10 million years prior to Archaeopteryx. Two extraordinary sites preserve evidence of miring, a highly unusual preservational milieu. Here we request support for 1) studies of undescribed fossils, including nearly complete skeletons of a basal lizard, a primitive mammal, an unusual new turtle, and a new maniraptoran theropod dinosaur, 2) preparation of detailed descriptions of several important dinosaur species, 3) radiometric dating (ID-TIMS) of rocks at the base of the Shishugou Formation, in contemporary rocks elsewhere in the Junggar Basin, and in the Middle Jurassic Shaximiao formations of Sichuan, China, and 4) continued exploration for fossils in the Shishugou Formation, especially in the lower part of the formation. Participants in this project include underrepresented groups in Earth Sciences (two females and a native American).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This joint project between American and Chinese paleontologists explored fossil deposits from a poorly known time period early in the rise of dinosaurs and close to the time that birds arose from dinosaurs. This grant, the second one for a project begun in 2001, funded field collection of fossil vertebrates, collection of rock samples for radiometric dating, and study of the fossils. Our main goal was to discover theropod dinosaurs relevant to the origin of birds, while any vertebrate from this poorly known time period is of great scientific importance.

            Two highly successful field seasons explored the Shishugou Formation of Xinjiang, northwestern China, which preserves terrestrial vertebrates from the late Middle to early Late Jurassic, approximately 160 million years ago. A third field season investigated related deposits in Inner Mongolia and a fourth field season searched for vertebrate fossils in deposits of the same age in Utah. We also visited the Shaximiao Formation of Sichuan, China to take rock samples for radiometric dating. Our dating of the Shishugou Formation indicates that nearly all of it is early Late Jurassic, while dating of the Shaximiao samples constrained its age to no older than Middle Jurassic.

            We discovered and described three new species of theropod dinosaurs, two new pterosaurs, and a new species of turtle from the Shishugou Formation. One of the new theropods, Haplocheirus, is the oldest alvarezsauroid, an enigmatic group previously known only from much later deposits and sometimes considered to be true birds. The other two new theropods, Zuolong and Aorun, are not as closely related to birds but are significant for understanding the evolution of theropods prior to the origin of birds. Aorun is represented by a juvenile for which we analyzed the effect of juvenile characters on understanding its evolutionary relationships. The pterodactyloid, Kryoptodrakon, is the oldest known pterodactyl, and implies that this important group originated in terrestrial environments, rather than marine ones. The exceptional material of turtles from the Shishugou formation includes four species in addition to the new one, the most complete material of turtles from this age.

            In addition to these published studies several studies are nearing completion. The theropod Limusaurus we first described during our earlier grant is highly unusual in having carnivore-type teeth as a juvenile and a toothless beak as an adult, indicating a drastic dietary shift during its lifetime. Exceptional material of a new species of terrestrial-adapted turtle helps to clarify the enigmatic group Mongolochelyidae. Two nearly complete skeletons of a new species of lizard are the oldest well-preserved remains of a squamate reptile.

            Our radiometric dating of the Shishugou Formation makes this fauna the best dated of any terrestrial fauna of this time period. This fauna is most similar to others in Central Asia, and differs from the Daohugou fauna of eastern China in many regards even though they are supposedly the same age. In particular, the Daohugou fauna includes several taxa closer to birds than any theropods in the Shishugou fauna. This suggests that either a biogeographic barrier separated these faunas or that the Daohugou fauna is younger than its current dates suggest.
